Award.AwardTitle: CIF: IHCS: Medium: Collaborative Research: Design and Implementation of Position-Encoded 3D Microarrays

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
This research involves design and building of a three-dimensional (3D) microarray device, with position-controlled microspheres, to perform simultaneous, efficient, and accurate screening of complementary DNAs, RNAs, and protein receptors on a single platform. This new device is portable, self-contained, automatic, and cost effective. Applications of this device include medical screening, drug discovery, and gene sequencing. In particular, it performs inexpensive disease diagnosis and provide insight into the molecular basis in different patients.

In existing 3D microarrays, microspheres are placed randomly within a substrate. This random placement of the microspheres makes their packing inefficient and their data processing complex. To overcome these drawbacks, the investigators design and build new microarrays with position-controlled microspheres. They analyze the statistical accuracy in estimating the target concentrations by computing performance bounds, and apply the results to select the minimal distance between the microspheres and the best operating temperature, while ensuring desired optimal estimation accuracy. The minimal microsphere distance enables high packing, and the optimal temperature reduces the cost. The investigators implement the position-controlled microarray using a microfluidic approach; particularly, they emplace the microspheres using a hydrodynamic trapping mechanism and using on-chip microvalves and pumps. The long-term goal is to integrate this device with image sensors, electronics, and optofluidic imaging to build a complete lab-on-a-chip system.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main goal of this project was to design and implement 3D microarrays for biomoledue detection with position-encoded microspheres. Microarrays are widely used in biology and medicine for multiplex biomarker detection and studies such genomic and proteomic analysis.

By using microfluidics technology, we have successfuly demonstrated, to our knowledge, the first smartphone controlled handheld microfluidic system which can be used broadly for microarrays, cell sorting and point-of-care medical diagnostic applications including HIV diagnosis. During the project, we have trained over 10 graduate, undergraduate ang high school students on cutting edge micro/nanofabrication, computer modeling and biotechnology. We have also developed an open-source numerical modeling package that can be freely downloaded by researchers in this field to simulate microfluidic single cell/particle trapps. The model is freely availble on our website: https://sites.google.com/site/gwulilab/research/singlecell 

The scientific findings and technology developement from this project have been published in peer-reviewed journals such as Biomicrofluidics, Lab on a Chip, bioconjugate Chemstry, and Journal of Micro/nanolithography, MEMS and MOEMS. We also reported our results at scientific conferences such as SPIE MEMS, Next Generation Dx Summit etc. We have also filed for a US provitional patent of the handheld microfludics technology developed during this project. Such technology can be used to build handheld medical diagnostic instruments for analyzing cells, proteins and DNAs in blood or other bodily fluids, an important enabling technology for personalized and precision medicine.
